Situation1: They review a construction project where certain elements could pose safety risks if not corrected before work continues.
Situation2: Medical advice suggests this may be their final opportunity to travel long distances.
Story: I sat at my desk, blueprints spread before me, red pen in hand. The structural calculations for the new community center didn’t add up—if we didn’t reinforce the beams, the building could be unsafe. As the lead architect, it was my duty to halt construction until the issues were fixed. My phone buzzed with a reminder: the Hajj application deadline was tomorrow. My doctor’s words echoed in my mind—my health was declining, and this year might be my last chance to fulfill my lifelong dream as a Muslim. My team and the clients expected me to oversee every detail of the project, especially now, when safety was at stake. But my heart ached at the thought of missing Hajj, a pillar of my faith. I felt torn, the weight of responsibility pressing from both sides. If I left now, would I be neglecting my duty to protect others? If I stayed, would I lose my only chance to answer the call to pilgrimage? My hands trembled as I stared at the calendar, caught between two worlds, unable to move.
